titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Collection in the Library of Congress
titlestmt.author: Prepared by Manuscript Division Staff

Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Manuscript Division

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Humorist, political commentator, and playwright. Correspondence, columns, book manuscripts, speeches, plays, screenplays, biographical material, photographs, audiovisual material, digital files, posters, memorabilia, drawings, appointment calendars, address books, artifacts, copyright registration and renewals, legal documents, financial records, and clippings documenting Buchwald's career as a columnist and his personal life.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

persname.part: Buchwald, Art. I'll always have Paris : a memoir. 1996.
Buchwald, Art. King for a day. 1982.
Buchwald, Art. Leaving home: a memoir. 1993.
Buchwald, Art. Sheep on the runway. 1970.
Buchwald, Art. Too soon to say goodbye. 2006.

corpname.part: Hebrew Orphan Asylum of New York.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The papers of Art Buchwald, humorist, political commentator, and playwright were purchased by the Library of Congress from Joel and Tamara Buchwald in 2017.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The papers of Art Buchwald were processed by Colleen Benoit Kim with the assistance of Tracey Barton, Thomas Bigley, Rebecca Gourevitch, Margaret McAleer, Kathleen O'Neill, Laney Stevenson, and Tammi Taylor in 2019. The collection came to the Library well organized by Buchwald's family members, chiefly his daughter-in-law, Tamara Buchwald. Refinements to the arrangement were made across the collection to improve its navigation, though many file groupings were maintained as received. This is especially true in the General Correspondence series, where the designations of "Close friends" and "VIP" were retained.

Digital files were received as part of the Art Buchwald Papers on a variety of storage media, each of which was assigned a unique digital ID number. Extensive duplication of files across and within storage media was present. Where possible, duplicate and closely similar files were removed, though heavy duplication of material is still present among the digital files. Buchwald's Apple iBook G3/600 was also received with the collection. A forensic disk image of the laptop was created and access was gained through an OS 9 emulation using SheepShaver. At this time, files from the contents of the laptop computer are not available.

otherfindaid.head: Additional Description
otherfindaid.p: A partial list of significant correspondents found in the General Correspondence: VIP Chronological file is appended to this finding aid as Appendix A.

A small portion of Buchwald's word-processing disks are inventoried by file name and type (i.e. column, speech, letter). A searchable PDF copy of this inventory is appended to this finding aid as Appendix B.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: Video cassettes, audio cassettes, and reels featuring interviews, speeches, and recordings of Buchwald's radio show, Buchwald On: The Art Buchwald Radio Program, have been transferred to the Motion Picture, Broadcasting, and Recorded Sound Division where they are identified as part of the Art Buchwald Papers.

Photographs of Buchwald, his family, and friends, especially the Kennedy family and those who also lived in Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts, as well as many notable cartoonists' depictions of Buchwald have been transferred to the Prints and Photographs Division where they are identified as part of the Art Buchwald Papers.
Patrons are encouraged to contact these divisions in advance of a research visit.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Copyright in the unpublished writings of Art Buchwald in these papers and in other collections in the custody of the Library of Congress is reserved. Consult reference staff in the Manuscript Division for further information.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of Art Buchwald are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

altformavail.head: Digital Format
altformavail.p: Digital files were received as part of the Art Buchwald Papers on a variety of storage media, each of which was assigned a unique digital ID number. Use the digital ID number to request access copies of the files. Access to digital content is available onsite only in the Manuscript Reading Room and requires advance notice. Consult reference staff in the Manuscript Division for more information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container or digital ID number, Art Buchwald Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p:
The papers of Art Buchwald (1925-2007) span the years 1885 to 2007, with the bulk of the material dating from 1962 to 2000. The collection documents Buchwald’s career as a humorist and columnist, as well as many aspects of his personal life and relationships. The papers are organized into nine series: General Correspondence, Writings,
Buchwald v. Paramount Pictures Corporation , Administrative File, Speeches, Personal File, Subject File, Digital File, and Oversize.

The collection extensively documents Buchwald’s work as a syndicated columnist in Europe (1949-1962) and the United States (1962-2006), as well as his work as an author, playwright, and public speaker. These papers primarily focus on Buchwald’s professional pursuits, especially his years in Washington, D.C., while working for the
Washington Post , though evidence of his personal relationships with entertainers, political figures, print and broadcast journalists, musicians, literary figures, friends, and family members form a significant part of the collection. These papers further illustrate the many connections Buchwald made during his life in Paris, France, Washington, D.C., and summers in Martha’s Vineyard, Massachusetts. Buchwald’s papers also broadly chronicle his youth and include material related to his childhood in the Hebrew Orphan Asylum and New York City’s foster care system, service in the United States Marine Corps during World War II, education at the University of Southern California, and his efforts to establish himself as a writer in Paris in the late 1940s and 1950s. Buchwald’s illnesses later in life, stay in hospice care, and death in 2007 are also documented in this collection. To a lesser extent, these papers reflect Buchwald’s lifelong struggle with depression. Though more minimally documented, this marks an important aspect of Buchwald’s life and character.
The collection’s series are listed and briefly described below. A fuller description of each series and a list of its contents can be accessed in the series descriptions within the container list.

The General Correspondence series is composed primarily of incoming letters Buchwald received from friends, colleagues, and relatives. The series is organized into three major groupings: VIP, Close friends, and Chronological. The “VIP” and “Close friends” designations were maintained as received and include letters from a wide variety of notable political and public figures.

The Writings series forms the largest portion of the collection and documents Buchwald’s work as a columnist, novelist, autobiographer, and playwright and documents his many articles, books, columns, memoirs, plays, and screenplays.

The Buchwald v. Paramount Pictures Corporation series chronicles a lawsuit Buchwald and producer, Alain Bernheim, filed against Paramount Pictures in 1988 for breach of contract in the development of a treatment for the film Coming to America .
The Administrative File largely pertains to Buchwald’s career management, finances, and public persona.

The Speeches series documents events and engagements for which Buchwald served as a speaker or master of ceremonies, was honored, or attended and includes remarks and scheduling information related to his many appearances at events, conferences, conventions, organizational meetings, charity benefits, award banquets, and commencements.

The Personal File chronicles Buchwald’s childhood in foster care in New York City, service in the United States Marine Corps during WWII, education at the University of Southern California, early career in Paris, France, family, health, and death.

The Subject File holds a wide range of files pertaining to Buchwald’s personal interests, organizations and charities he supported, and organizations in which Buchwald was indirectly or directly involved, among other topics.
The Digital File series contains the contents of a personal computer and word-processing disks created and used by Buchwald between 1987 and 2006.
The remaining series houses Oversize and unusually formatted material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in nine series:

scopecontent.p: The General Correspondence series is composed primarily of incoming letters Buchwald received from friends, colleagues, and relatives. The series is organized into three groupings: VIP, Close friends, and Chronological. The “VIP” and “Close friends” designations were maintained as received and include letters from a wide variety of notable political and public figures. The VIP grouping is further arranged into an alphabetical file and a chronological file. Correspondents represented in the VIP alphabetical file include Alain Bernheim, Benjamin C. Bradlee, Katharine Graham, Ann Landers, Gordon Manning, Florence Leola Starling, David L. Wolper, members of the Kennedy family, several cartoonists, and members of Congress, among others. The VIP chronological file also contains letters from many notable figures. Appendix A contains a partial list of significant correspondents found in the VIP chronological file. Al Hix and Lucy D. and Sheldon Hackney, among others, appear in the Close friends file. Though efforts were made to reduce overlap of correspondents across groupings, names may appear in more than one of the groupings in this series.

Letters across the General Correspondence series are largely personal in nature and chronicle Buchwald’s relationships with entertainers, political figures, print and broadcast journalists, musicians, literary figures, and friends. This series broadly reflects Buchwald's many circles of friends, especially those associated with Paris, Washington, D.C., and Georgetown specifically, summers in Martha's Vineyard, and Hollywood, as well as others working in the news industry. Topics covered vary based on the correspondent, but many letters detail life in Paris, time in the United States Marine Corps, shared personal history or acquaintances, projects and events in which Buchwald participated, and responses to his columns and books. The humor shared between Buchwald and his friends is well documented in this series.

arrangement.p: Arranged into three groupings: VIP, Close friends, and Chronological and arranged alphabetically by name or chronologically therein.

scopecontent.p:
The Writings series forms the largest portion of the collection and documents Buchwald’s work as a columnist, novelist, autobiographer, and playwright and documents his many articles, books, columns, memoirs, plays, and screenplays. A nearly complete chronological run of Buchwald’s columns is contained in this series and dates between 1949 and 2006. The columns take the form of newspaper clippings and drafts bearing Buchwald’s edits. Russian translations of Buchwald’s columns as they appeared in Soviet periodicals, especially Prâvda , are also included. These translations date primarily between 1958 and 1969 and were sent to Buchwald by a variety of sources, among them, Radio Free Europe, the United States Information Agency, and a reader named Misha Allen. Material related to Buchwald’s numerous books, most of which are anthologies of his columns and articles, are also contained in this series and are largely documented by correspondence with publishers, friends, and readers, book reviews, and other publishing work product. Buchwald’s memoirs, Leaving Home ,
I’ll Always Have Paris , and Too Soon to Say Goodbye , are heavily documented in the Writings series and include digital and analog manuscript drafts, letters from readers, and background research. Unpublished works include a collection of letters titled “Read Between the Lines” and an autobiography titled “Revenge is Sweet.” Many of Buchwald’s play scripts and screenplays are also represented in this series, with Sheep on the Runway , which was performed on Broadway from 1969 to 1970, and his first play, No Love Atoll , performed at the University of Southern California Varsity Show in 1948, among the most well documented. Researchers should note additional column drafts and book manuscripts can be found in the Digital File series. Some of Buchwald's earliest writings, including articles written while in the United States Marine Corps and as coursework while at the University of Southern California are found in the Personal File.
Material types include articles, book manuscripts, book reviews, columns, correspondence, digital files, lists, newspaper clippings, photographs, and printed matter.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by type of publication and alphabetically by title or topic or chronologically therein. File structure of the digital content included in this series was maintained as received.

scopecontent.p: The Buchwald v. Paramount Pictures Corporation series chronicles a lawsuit Buchwald and producer, Alain Bernheim, filed against Paramount Pictures in 1988 for breach of contract in the development of a film treatment. The suit was filed in the state of California on Buchwald’s claim that Paramount Pictures based their film Coming to America on his and Bernheim’s treatment titled “King for a Day,” thereby violating their contract agreements providing them compensation and credit if Paramount Pictures produced a movie based on their creative work. Buchwald was ultimately awarded damages in 1992. This series comprehensively documents the legal proceedings of the suit and includes draft copies of Buchwald's "King for a Day" and the screenplay directly based on his treatment, the initial complaint filed in 1988, briefs, motions, memoranda, depositions, and court transcripts. Correspondence from friends and colleagues reflect reactions to the suit and its outcome and a collection of clippings and a scrapbook chronicle press coverage of the case.
Material types include briefs, correspondence, dispositions, memoranda, motions, newspaper clippings, and transcripts.

The Administrative File documents Buchwald’s management of his career, finances, and public persona. This series extensively chronicles Buchwald’s financial status, speaking engagement logistics, and publishing matters such as copyrights, royalties, and syndication. A chronological file focuses on Buchwald’s speaking engagements and finances and includes contracts, correspondence with event organizers, travel itineraries, monthly expense records, and monthly financial statements, which list sources of income, net worth, and expenses. Evidence of Buchwald’s public persona and celebrity is found in a publicity file, which comprises newspaper clippings featuring articles about Buchwald, biographical material, interview transcripts, and digital audio and video files of interviews with Buchwald, especially toward the end of his life while in hospice care. Contracts, storyboards, correspondence, programs, brochures, and screenplays reflecting a number of television, radio, stage, and screen production projects are also found in this series and include correspondence and program synopses of Buchwald’s radio program Buchwald On. Projects documented in this series range from Buchwald’s active involvement and creative participation to projects where he granted permission to others to use his works. Material in this series reflects Buchwald’s involvement in production projects from an administrative perspective and does not include Buchwald’s creative works. Researchers should consult the Writings series for Buchwald’s creative works as an author and playwright and the Speeches series for transcripts of Buchwald’s remarks at speaking engagements.
Material types include contracts, copyright renewals, correspondence, digital files, expense reports, financial statements, itineraries, newspaper clippings, photographs, and royalty statements.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by topic or material type. File structure of the digital content included in this series was maintained as received.

scopecontent.p: The Speeches series documents events and engagements for which Buchwald served as a speaker or master of ceremonies, was honored, or attended and includes remarks and scheduling information related to his many appearances at events, conferences, conventions, organizational meetings, charity benefits, award banquets, and commencements. A number of Buchwald’s speeches were given at professional organization meetings or for organizations that played important roles in his life such as the Hebrew Orphan Asylum of New York and the New York Herald Tribune . Some of Buchwald’s remarks were given in recognition of awards he received and include honorary degrees, the National Press Club's Fourth Estate Award, and the Horatio Alger Award. Tributes or remembrances given by Buchwald in honor of friends or family members are also documented. Of note is a script Buchwald revised for a production in partnership with the Boston Pops Orchestra of Saint-Saens’ Carnival of the Animals , which includes numerous scripts, correspondence, and press clippings related to the program. Major themes and topics in the speeches include childhood and leaving home, Buchwald’s service in the United States Marine Corps, his years spent in Paris, France, politics and life in Washington, D.C., and depression and mental health.
Material types include speeches, in both complete and fragmented form, speech cards, notes and transcripts, programs and invitations, correspondence, clippings, photographs, and negatives.

scopecontent.p:
The Personal File documents Buchwald’s youth, early career in Paris, France, family, health, and death. The bulk of the material chronicles Buchwald’s childhood in the Hebrew Orphan Asylum’s foster care system, service in the United States Marine Corps, and years at the University of Southern California. Documents and printed ephemera reflecting Buchwald’s fourteen years in Paris (1948-1962) are comprised in this series and document his work as a critic and humorist for the
New York Herald Tribune , as well as his household and family life at that time. The Personal File also contains Buchwald’s family papers, which include letters with his sisters, in-laws, and other family members and documents collected and created by Buchwald’s wife, Ann. Ann Buchwald’s papers contain correspondence with Art and other members of her family, as well as transcripts and drafts of her memoir, Seems Like Yesterday . Early examples of Buchwald’s writings are found throughout the Personal File beginning with a poem written when he was twelve years old, circa 1937. Several newsletters for which Buchwald wrote while in the United States Marine Corps, including The Coral Courier and The U-Man Comedy , are also in this series. His academic essays, produced for courses in creative and script writing at the University of Southern California, are well represented, as are pieces written for school publications, The Daily Trojan and WAMPUS . This series also includes early columns Buchwald wrote while in Paris. These consist of articles written in 1948 when he was a stringer for
Variety and article drafts for the New York Herald Tribune .

Material types include address and appointment books, correspondence, digital files, family papers, honorary degrees and awards, oral histories, medical files, military documents, identification cards, marriage documents, photographs, and wills.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by topic or material type. File structure of the digital content included in this series was maintained as received.

scopecontent.p: The Subject File holds a wide range of files pertaining to Buchwald’s personal interests, organizations and charities he supported, and organizations in which he was involved, among other topics. Buchwald’s many charitable contributions are documented in this series and include scholarships he funded, undergraduate students he sponsored, monetary donations to nonprofit organizations, prizes he donated for charitable auctions, which was usually the right to name a character in one of his upcoming columns, and his service as the auctioneer for the annual Possible Dreams auction in Martha’s Vineyard. Many humor conferences and organizations are represented in this series and include material regarding an exchange of American and Soviet humorists in 1988, for which Buchwald traveled to the Soviet Union. Letters from readers are included in the Subject File and record reactions to some of Buchwald’s columns. Correspondence and printed matter chronicle Buchwald’s ongoing relationships with the New York Herald Tribune , United States Marine Corps, and University of Southern California. Researchers should consult the Personal File for material more directly related to Buchwald’s early career with the New York Herald Tribune while in Paris, France, his service as a Marine, and his tenure as a student at the University of Southern California.
Material types include brochures, correspondence, newspaper clippings, programs, and printed matter.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by topic or material type.

scopecontent.p: The Digital File series contains the contents of a personal computer and word-processing disks created and used by Buchwald between 1987 and 2006. The series documents his professional activities during this period and focuses primarily on speech and column drafts, though to a lesser extent, correspondence and photographs are also represented. The file structure of the digital content has been maintained as received and Buchwald’s word-processing files were saved in no particular chronological or topical order, resulting in a mix of date ranges, subjects, and document types across digital ID numbers. In general, speeches and columns found on disks range in date from 1987 to 1996, while those found on Buchwald’s personal computer range in date from 2002 to 2006. An inventory of some of the disks was created, presumably by one of Buchwald's assistants, and a PDF copy is appended to the finding aid as Appendix B. Correspondence was saved among column and speech drafts and dates between 1987 and 1996. In an effort to ensure correspondence was not overlooked among the digital files, digital ID numbers containing letters are listed under “Correspondence” and under “Columns and speeches.” Correspondence found in the Digital File series includes several letters Buchwald wrote to his wife, Ann, during their separation and her cancer treatments. Letters from Buchwald to his children and friends are also found in this series. In other instances where digital materials were found with the collection’s paper content, the digital materials are listed and described alongside the paper records.
Material types include book manuscripts, correspondence, photographs, and speech and column drafts.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by material type and listed by digital ID number thereunder, with the file structure of the digital content maintained as received.

did.didnote: The contents of Buchwald's laptop are currently unavailable.

scopecontent.p: Oversize and unusually formatted material feature a commemorative cigar associated with Buchwald's radio program Buchwald On , a crank toy in the form of Buchwald at a book signing for his memoir, Leaving Home , the prosthetic leg Buchwald wore after his leg was amputated in 2006, and many promotional posters associated with Buchwald's columns and books. Other material includes storyboards, photographs, drawings, speech cards, and scrapbooks.

arrangement.p: Listed and described according to the series, containers, and folders from which the material was removed. Physically grouped and housed by size of the items, with containers numbered sequentially according to the physical arrangement.

odd.head: Appendix A: Partial list of Significant Correspondents in the VIP Chronological File
odd.p: The list below highlights some of the significant correspondents represented in the VIP Chronological grouping of the General Correspondence series. The below is not a comprehensive list of all names found in the grouping.

odd.head: Appendix B: Partial Disk Inventory
odd.p: Attached is a searchable PDF copy of an inventory created by Buchwald or an assistant of some of his word-processing disks. The inventory lists file names across fifteen disks and classifies files as "column," "speech," or "letter." Date spans are not indicated on the inventory. The digital ID for each disk is noted in brackets on the inventory.
